journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Preparation and characterization of nanocomposites based on amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes and bismaleimide resin

article-meta.aff: Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Yi Zhang, Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an 710129, PR China Email: zhangyi520love@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this work, a novel nanocomposite consisting of bismaleimide resin (BMI) and amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes (NH2-MWNTs) have been discussed. The fluorinating MWNTs (F-MWNTs) were synthesized by solid-phase method and the NH2-MWNTs were prepared by interaction of the F-MWNTs with 1,2-diaminoethane. The NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites have been prepared by solution blend method. Their morphology and properties were characterized by transmission electron microscope, fourier transmission infrared, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, etc. The results showed that impurities in the MWNTs were removed after the purification treatment and amine groups have been successfully attached to the purified MWNTs. The impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites increased firstly as the NH2-MWNTs increased and then decreased. When the content of the NH2-MWNTs is 0.6 wt%, the impact strength of nanocomposites is optimal (about 12.57 kJ/m2) which increase by 58.51% compared with the neat BMI resin.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The reinforcement of polymers with nano-scaled fillers developed a new class of advanced multifunctional materials with improved properties, used in many fields ranging from microelectronics to aerospace.1,2 Among nanofillers, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are popular fillers due to their exceptional mechanical, thermal and electrical properties and many potential applications.3–7 Research findings have shown that enhancement in the strength is obtainable in CNTs/epoxy,8 CNTs/polymethylmethacrylate,9 CNTs/natural rubber,10 CNTs/silicone rubber,11 CNTs/polyetheretherketone composites,12 etc.

Although there are some papers on CNTs reinforced polymer composites, it is difficult to realize the expected enhancement in the properties of the composites, such as mechanical properties. The reason is that CNTs have strong tendency to exist in agglomerated form through their huge surface area, which leads to non-homogeneous dispersion and random distribution of the CNTs inside the resin.13 Additional processing difficulty is that the atomically smooth nonreactive surface of CNTs inhibits load transfer from the matrix to CNTs across the CNTs/polymer interface because CNTs are built of rolled graphene sheets and lack interfacial bonding. In these cases, nanotubes are easily pulled out from the matrix, rather than fractured, which limit their reinforcement properties.14

In order to overcome these problems, functionalized CNTs were developed which can homogeneously disperse in the resin and provide multiple bonding sites to the polymer matrix.15–19 The functionalizing methods can be simply be classified into covalent and non-covalent approaches. Compared with non-covalent (physical) approach, covalent approach can maintain the fruits of functionalization and show promising future.20 Nowadays, many functionalized CNTs by covalent approach are researched. Among them, amino-functionalized CNTs have been studied because amino group has a high reactivity and thus can be directly incorporated into many polymer matrix. The hydrophobic nature of the as-received CNTs surface becomes more hydrophilic after amine treatments which brings high dispersion in the resin.21,22 However, the conventional method to functionalize CNTs with amino groups is generally a complicated process involving a long reaction time, toxic coupling reagents (SOCl2), and strictly controlled reaction conditions. Therefore, we adopt an easy approach to prepare amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes (NH2-MWNTs) by refluxing fluorinating MWNTs (F-MWNTs) which were synthesized by solid-phase method in 1,2-diaminoethane.

Bismaleimide (BMI) is a leading thermosetting polymer owing to its low moisture absorption, high glass-transition temperature and good thermal stability, etc. So it has attracted much attention for various applications including aerospace and electronic industries. However, cured BMI exhibits remarkable brittleness and poor processing characteristics owing to its high crosslink density, poor solubility in ordinary solvents, and high crystalline melting point of BMI monomers.23 Many researchers have done a lot of work to improve the toughness of cured BMI.24–26 However, the studies employing the NH2-MWNTs which were prepared by interactions of F-MWNTs with the terminal diamines to toughen BMI are very limited. In this article, MWNTs were modified by polytetrafluoroethylene and 1,2-diaminoethane to improve the dispersion of MWNTs in the resin thus obtaining NH2-MWNTs. Then the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were prepared by solution blend method. The morphology and properties of the MWNTs, the NH2-MWNTs and the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), fourier transform infrared (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), etc.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: MWNTs with a purity of 90% used in the present study, synthesized via catalyst-assisted chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process, were purchased from Chengdu Alpha Nano Technology Co., Ltd. The powder of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) was supplied by HuBei Fengguang Chemicals. The 98% nitric acid (HNO3), 36% hydrochloric acid (HCl), 1,2-diaminoethane (H2N(CH2)2NH2), pyridine (Py) and acetone (ACE) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. BMI was obtained from Ning Rongchang research group of Northwestern Polytechnical University. All chemicals were of regent grade and were used as received. Distilled water was used during sample preparation.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: The crude MWNTs were stirred in 3 M nitric acid and refluxed for 24 h at 105°C, and then were suspended and refluxed in 5 M HCl solution for 10 h at 110°C. After acid treatment, the samples were calcined in static air at 500°C with the reaction time of about 1.0 h, and the purified MWNTs were obtained.

After purification procedure, the F-MWNTs were prepared using the following procedure. Firstly, the purified MWNTs and PTFE were well mixed and the proportion of MWNTs and PTFE was 1:9. Then the mixture was heated to 450°C for 2 h in sealed vessel. When PTFE was heated to 450°C, PTFE was broken down and generated fluorine onium ion. The fluorine onium ion reacted with the C=C double bonds of the MWNTs and formed the two new C–F σ bonds.27 In order to clean off the PTFE residues after fluorination, the samples were dispersed in distilled water via ultrasonic technique. PTFE residues sank while F-MWNTs were homogeneously dispersed in distilled water. The suspension of F-MWNTs in distilled water was poured out and filtrated. Lastly, pure F-MWNTs were obtained after being washed thoroughly with distilled water and dried in vacuum at 100°C for 2 h.

The NH2-MWNTs were prepared in a 250 mL, four-necked, round-bottom ﬂask equipped with a reﬂux condenser, an efﬁcient stirrer, N2 purge and a thermometer. First, plenty of H2N(CH2)2NH2 was poured into the flask. Then, appropriate amounts of F-MWNTs and catalytic amounts of Py were added to the flask. The reaction temperature was kept 115°C and the reaction time was 6 h. Upon being filtered, the precipitates were washed with redistilled water thoroughly and dried in vacuum at 100°C for 2 h and the pure NH2-MWNTs were obtained. The reactions were illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration showing the procedure for preparation the NH2-MWNTs.
NH2-MWNTs: amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

The NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were prepared by solution blend method. At first, BMI was heated to 110°C and kept at this temperature for a moment until it melted. Then the NH2-MWNTs were dispersed in acetone with ultrasonically stirring at 30°C for 1 h. Then, the appropriate amounts of the suspension was added into melted BMI at 115°C and kept at this temperature with stirring for 1 h. And then, the mixture was poured into a preheated mold using a release agent, and degassed in a vacuum drying oven at 115°C for 1 h. At last, the NH2-MWNTs/ BMI nanocomposites were cured following the schedule of 150°C /1 h + 180°C/2 h + 200°C/2 h. A post-curing process was performed at 220°C for 4 h. Neat BMI samples were prepared in the same manner as above.

sec.title: Characterization and property
sec.p: The transmission electron microscope (H-800 model, Japan) was used to analyze the internal morphology of the crude MWNTs and the purified MWNTs.
Fourier transform infrared spectrum (IRpresitge-21 model, China) was used to record fourier transforms infrared spectra of the purified MWNTs, the F-MWNTs and the NH2-MWNTs.
The XRD was performed using a XRD-7000 instrument (X’ Pert MPD PRO type, Holland) at a scan rate of 0.02°. The X-ray patterns for 2θ from 10° to 80° were obtained.
Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) image of the NH2-MWNTs was collected by JSM-6360LV (JEOL Company).

The NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites castings were cut using a grinding wheel cutter into cuboid of 15.0 mm × 10.0 mm × 4.0 mm for impact strength. Five specimens were tested for each test and average values were reported.
The micro morphology of neat BMI resin and the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were investigated by SEM. The fracture surface was coated with gold by vapor deposition.

sec.title: Characterization of the crude MWNTs, the purified MWNTs, the F-MWNTs and the NH2-MWNTs
sec.p:
Various synthesis methods have been developed for the production of CNTs. However, all the raw materials produced by these methods contain impurities of amorphous carbon, graphite particles and metal catalysts. Purification of CNTs is very important for applications using their excellent intrinsic properties. To verify the validity of purification treatment for MWNTs, we performed TEM imaging of MWNTs both before and after purification treatment. Results from this analysis are shown in Figure 2. Many bundles with a diameter ranging from 40 to 60 nm can be seen in Figure 2(a), together with some dark lumps and dark spots which are amorphous carbon and metal catalyst nanoparticles. No visible impurities, including amorphous carbon and metal catalyst nanoparticles, are detected in Figure 2(b) after the purification treatment. The TEM images indicate that the purification treatment is effective. Figure 2.
TEM images of (a) crude MWNTs and (b) purified MWNTs.
MWNTs: multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

The FTIR technique was used to monitor the MWNTs’ structural changes caused by the surface modification. The FTIR spectra of the purified MWNTs (a), the F-MWNTs (b) and the NH2-MWNTs (c) are shown in Figure 3. Both samples have absorption peak appeared at 2250 cm−1, which belongs to CO2 physisorbed on samples’ surface. The peak at 3430 cm−1 in Figure 3(a) is attributed to the presence of OH group on the surface of the purified MWNTs.28 For the F-MWNTs, Figure 3(b) shows a new absorption peak appeared at 1215 cm−1 compared to the FTIR spectrum in Figure 3(a), which is characteristic of covalent C–F bond stretching.29 The FTIR spectrum of the NH2-MWNTs (Figure 3(c)) shows the peak at 1645 cm−1 which can be attributed to the NH2 scissoring mode and the peak at 3540 cm−1 which may be due to the N–H stretch of the amine (NH2) group.30 Two peaks around 2920 cm−1 and 2837 cm−1 show the C–H stretching mode of methylene in ethylenediamine molecule.31 From the FTIR spectrum of Figure 3(c), the existence of amine groups attached to the MWNTs is clear. Figure 3.
FTIR spectra of (a) purified MWNTs, (b) F-MWNTs and (c) NH2-MWNTs.
MWNTs: multi-wall carbon nanotubes; F-MWNTs: fluorinating multi-wall carbon nanotubes; NH2-MWNTs: amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

XRD patterns are used in further study of the changes in structure. XRD peaks of the crude MWNTs (a), the purified MWNTs (b) and the F-MWNTs (c) are listed in Figure 4. There are a sharp and intense peak at 2θ = 26.4° and a weak peak in Figure 4(a), corresponding to (002) and (110) planes of typical graphitized MWNTs, respectively. Two weak peaks at 2θ = 44.5° and 76.4° also can be observed in Figure 4(a) and indexed to the (111) and (220) planes of cubic fcc-type Ni crystals (JCPDS, File No. 65-2865) which indicates that the metal catalyst residual in the crude MWNTs by CVD is nickel. After the purification process, it can be found that the (111) and (220) planes in Figure 4(b) are disappeared which demonstrates the Ni catalyst residuals have been eliminated. The (002) and (110) planes in Figure 4(b) are stronger than that in Figure 4(a) which reveals the amorphous carbon coating the surface of MWNTs is consumed by oxidation reaction. Figure 4(c) is the XRD pattern of the F-MWNTs. The (002) and (110) planes of MWNTs also can be observed in Figure 4(c). In addition, there are two new peaks at 2θ = 15.0° and 46.8°, corresponding to (001) and (003) planes. The relative intensities and positions of these two peaks agree well with those in the XRD pattern of the CNTs fluoride CFx which reported in other studies.32,33 Figure 4.
XRD patterns of (a) crude MWNTs, (b) purified MWNTs and (c) F-MWNTs.
XRD: X-ray diffraction; MWNTs: multi-wall carbon nanotubes; F-MWNTs: fluorinating multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

In order to analyze the content of N of the NH2-MWNTs, EDS was performed. Figure 5 shows the EDS results of the NH2-MWNTs. EDS spectrum of the NH2-MWNTs clearly depicts peaks for C, O and N. The elementary analysis for the NH2-MWNTs shows that the content of C, O and N are 95.44 wt%, 1.26 wt% and 3.30 wt%, respectively. The elementary analysis for the NH2-MWNTs indicates that amine groups have been successfully attached to the MWNTs. Figure 5.
EDS spectrum of the NH2-MWNTs.
EDS: energy dispersive spectroscopy; NH2-MWNTs: amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

sec.title: Mechanical properties of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites
sec.p:
The dependency of the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites on the content of the NH2-MWNTs is shown in Figure 6. The data shown in Figure 6 is the average value of five samples for each formulation. Figure 6 shows that the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites first increased with the NH2-MWNTs content increasing. When the content of filler increased to 0.6 wt%, the impact strength reached to the highest value of 12.57 kJ/m2. After that, the impact strength then gradually decreased. As can be seen, with the addition of the NH2-MWNTs, the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites increased significantly. The impact strength is optimal with 0.6 wt% NH2-MWNTs. In comparison to the neat BMI, the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites with 0.6 wt% NH2-MWNTs increase by 58.51%. The NH2-MWNTs may well disperse in the BMI and may have an effect of physical crosslinking points in the BMI. There would be crack in NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites on impact. The crack can be deflected at a crosslinking points and that it is forced to move out of the initial propagation plane by tilting and twisting.34,35 Such deflection causes a change in the stress state from the neat BMI to NH2-MWNTs. To propagate crack in the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites requires a higher driving force than in neat BMI, which results in a higher impact strength of the material. However, this improvement is true only when the NH2-MWNTs have a good distribution in the nanocomposites. When the content of the NH2-MWNTs is high, the NH2-MWNTs could not well disperse in the BMI matrix and agglomerate to cluster. The agglomeration caused the uneven distribution of internal stress in the nanocomposites. So the average impact strength gradually decreased. Figure 6.
The impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites under various contents of the NH2-MWNTs.
NH2-MWNTs: amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes; BMI: bismaleimide.

sec.title: Structure of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows SEM of fracture surfaces in the impact test of samples. Figure 7(a) to (d) present the fracture source of neat BMI resin, the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites with 0.2 wt%, 0.6 wt% and 0.8 wt% NH2-MWNTs, respectively. The crackpropagation region of neat BMI resin and its nanocomposites is different. The fracture surface of neat BMI resin shown in Figure 7(a) is comparatively slippery. Compared with neat BMI resin, the fracture surface of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites shown in Figure 7(b) to (d) is rougher. There are some dimples on the fracture surface of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites. The dimples can consume more energy and reinforce the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites. Moreover, the number of dimples in Figure 7(c) is more than that in Figure 7(b) and Figure 7(d), which shows the impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites with 0.6 wt% NH2-MWNTs is optimal. In Figure 7(d), we can observe that there is apparant agglomeration on the fracture surface of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites with 0.8 wt% NH2-MWNTs. The agglomeration of the NH2-MWNTs could decrease the impact strength of the nanocomposites. So the SEM results are consistent with the impact strength shown in Figure 6. Figure 7.
SEM impact fractographs of (a) neat BMI resin, (b) NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites with 0.2 wt% NH2-MWNTs, (c) 0.6 wt% NH2-MWNTs (d) 0.8 wt% NH2-MWNTs.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy; BMI: bismaleimide; NH2-MWNTs: amino group-terminated multi-wall carbon nanotubes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were studied. Firstly, the MWNTs were purified by combining the acid refluxes and the oxidation in air. Then F-MWNTs were synthesized by solid-phase method. The NH2-MWNTs have been prepared by refluxing the F-MWNTs in H2N(CH2)2NH2 in the presence of a catalytic amounts of Py. And the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were prepared by mixing the NH2-MWNTs nanoparticles with BMI resin. Lastly, the NH2-MWNTs and the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites were characterized by TEM, FTIR, XRD, EDS, SEM, etc. TEM images indicate that impurities in the MWNTs were removed after the purification treatment. FTIR spectra indicate that amine groups have been successfully attached to the MWNTs. The elementary analysis shows that the content of N of the NH2-MWNTs is 3.30 wt%. The impact strength of the NH2-MWNTs/BMI nanocomposites increased firstly as the NH2-MWNTs increased, and reached the highest value of 12.57 kJ/m2 at the 0.6 wt% filler concentration and then decreased after that. When the content of the NH2-MWNTs is 0.6 wt%, the impact strength of nanocomposites is optimal which increase by 58.51% compared with the neat BMI resin.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Shaanxi Materials Analysis and Research Center for carrying out the XRD, TEM and SEM characterization. The authors also thank their colleagues in their laboratory for their support.
